raw_text:
Lib Dems target the student vote
 
 Students can decide the fate of MPs in some seats at the next election, Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy has claimed.
 
 The party says the votes of students can win it 27 new seats at the poll. The figures assume all students will vote in their university town. In fact, some may vote where the parents live. The Lib Dems say scrapping university fees wins them student support. But the Tories would also end fees and Labour says both would cap people's ambitions.
 
 The Lib Dems have named the 14 seats where there are enough students to take the Lib Dems from second place to beat Labour, and the 13 where they could go from second to beat the Tories. Launching his campaign to win students' votes at the London School of Economics, Mr Kennedy urged students to "make their mark". He underlined Lib Dem plans to scrap university fees and reintroduce maintenance grants of up to £2,000. He said: "Top-up fees put students off university, especially those from a poorer background. "And is it really right that so many young people are starting out in life with mortgage-style debts hanging round their necks?" Mr Kennedy also said students want action on the environment and see the Iraq war, which his party opposed, as a defining issue.
 
 Labour has pushed through plans to let universities charge fees of up to £3,000 a year, with the poorest students eligible for non-repayable support of up to £3,000. Ahead of Mr Kennedy's launch, a Labour spokesperson said: "Like the Tories, the Liberal Democrats would restrict access to higher education and put a cap on aspiration, closing the door to students with good grades and restricting their life ambitions. "They are committed to abandoning Labour's targets of getting 50% of 18 to 30-year-olds going into higher education and under Lib Dem plans students would even have to study near home." The Conservatives say they would abolish university tuition fees and instead offer large student loans at commercial rates of interest.
 
 They say the Lib Dem policy would leave universities wholly dependent for their income on the "goodwill" of the chancellor.
 
 Shadow education secretary Tim Collins is on Thursday setting out a new scheme of vocational grants for 14 to 16-year-olds to tackle what he says are "crippling skills shortages". The Lib Dem analysis of the difference students could make to its election chances is based on all students being registered to vote near their university, not in their home towns. Although the expected 5 May election would be during term time, students can vote by post. The Electoral Commission and National Union of Students are worried students in halls of residence can find it hard to register to vote. Some hall wardens are reluctant to register students because of data protection fears - but students can get themselves registered. If the election is on 5 May, voters need to register by 11 March.
 
 
  - The seats where the Lib Dems say student votes can swing the election for them are: Bristol West, Cardiff Central, Leeds North West, Cambridge, Manchester Gorton, Sheffield Central, Oxford East, Newcastle-upon-Tyne Central, Liverpool Riverside, Holborn and St Pancras, Oldham East and Saddleworth, Manchester Withington, Islington South and Finsbury, Birmingham Yardley, Surrey South West, Taunton, Orpington, Haltemprice and Howden, Eastbourne, Isle of Wight, Dorset West, Bournemouth East, Wells, Canterbury, Cities of London and Westminster, Bournemouth West, Westmorland and Lonsdale.
llama3.2:1b:
The Liberal Democrats are targeting the student vote in upcoming elections by promising to scrap university fees and cap access to higher education if they win seats. They claim this will increase their support from students who currently favor Labour or the Conservatives. 

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy has launched a campaign to win students' votes, proposing plans such as scrapping top-up fees and reintroducing maintenance grants of up to £2,000. Labour, on the other hand, supports higher education for all, but also proposes restricting access and capping aspirations.
llama3.2:3b: Liberal Democrats claim students' votes can win them 27 new seats by scrapping university fees and introducing maintenance grants up to £2,000. Labour says both parties would restrict access to higher education and cap aspirations, while the Conservatives would abolish fees with large student loans. The Lib Dem analysis assumes all students vote in their university towns, but some may vote in their hometowns.
gemma2:2b: The Liberal Democrats believe student votes will be crucial to their election success in the upcoming UK general election. They claim that students could swing 27 seats for them and are targeting university towns with policies like eliminating tuition fees and reintroducing maintenance grants.  Both Labour and Conservative parties have different plans regarding education funding, impacting students' opportunities for higher education. The Lib Dems plan to provide student support in the form of financial aid, while Labour has implemented a system of fees and student loans, arguing that both sides would restrict access to education.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Lib Dems believe student votes can significantly boost their chances at the next election by winning 27 new seats and possibly beating Labour in some seats. They propose a system where university students' tuition fees are abolished and maintenance grants are raised to £2,000, with top-up fees for those from poorer backgrounds being paid out as well. The party also advocates extending the voting period at universities so that more students can register to vote by post rather than in their homes.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Liberal Democrats target student vote in 14 seats to potentially gain 27 additional seats; claims students could win key university towns and universities themselves with fee reductions. The Lib Dems propose scrapping fees, offering maintenance grants of £2,000 per year, while Labour supports higher tuition fees but wants to cap access to higher education.
qwen2.5:3b: Liberal Democrats target student votes for electoral advantage, claiming they could gain 27 seats by assuming all students vote in their university towns. Their strategy includes plans to scrap university fees and reintroduce maintenance grants. Labour counters with fee increases capped at £3,000, while Conservatives propose abolishing tuition fees and offering subsidized loans. The Liberal Democrats argue top-up fees deter poorer students from attending university; they also emphasize environmental concerns and opposition to the Iraq war as key issues for students. Students can vote by post during term time, but registration challenges remain in halls of residence.

8. Launching his campaign to win students' votes at the London School of Economics, Mr Kennedy urged students to "make their mark".
9. Mr Kennedy underlined Lib Dem plans to scrap university fees and reintroduce maintenance grants of up to £2,000.
10. He said: "Top-up fees put students off university, especially those from a poorer background." 
11. And is it really right that so many young people are starting out in life with mortgage-style debts hanging round their necks? Mr Kennedy also said students want action on the environment and see the Iraq war, which his party opposed, as a defining issue.
12. Labour has pushed through plans to let universities charge fees of up to £3,000 a year, with the poorest students eligible for non-repayable support of up to £3,000. 
13. Ahead of Mr Kennedy's launch, a Labour spokesperson said: "Like the Tories, the Liberal Democrats would restrict access to higher education and put a cap on aspiration, closing the door to students with good grades and restricting their life ambitions." 
14. They are committed to abandoning Labour's targets of getting 50% of 18 to 30-year-olds going into higher education and under Lib Dem plans students would even have to study near home.
15. The Conservatives say they would abolish university tuition fees and instead offer large student loans at commercial rates of interest.
16. They say the Lib Dem policy would leave universities wholly dependent for their income on the "goodwill" of the chancellor.
17. Shadow education secretary Tim Collins is on Thursday setting out a new scheme of vocational grants for 14 to 16-year-olds to tackle what he says are "crippling skills shortages". 
18. The Lib Dem analysis of the difference students could make to its election chances is based on all students being registered to vote near their university, not in their home towns.
19. Although the expected 5 May election would be during term time, students can vote by post. The Electoral Commission and National Union of Students are worried students in halls of residence can find it hard to register to vote. Some hall wardens are reluctant to register students because of data protection fears - but students can get themselves registered. If the election is on 5 May, voters need to register by 11 March.
smollm:1.7b:

The Lib Dems say they would scrap university fees and reintroduce maintenance grants of up to £2,000 if they won the election. They also say that they would limit access to higher education for students who have already qualified with a good degree or equivalent.
The Labour party has pushed through plans to let universities charge fees of up to £3,000 a year and has committed to abolishing university tuition fees altogether. The Lib Dems would abolish university tuition fees and instead offer large student loans at commercial rates of interest. They say that they would leave universities wholly dependent for their income on the "goodwill" of the chancellor.
The Shadow education secretary Tim Collins is set to announce a new scheme of vocational grants for 14 to 16-year-olds to tackle what he says are "crippling skills shortages". The Lib Dems analysis of the difference students can make to its election chances is based on all students being registered to vote near their university, not in their home towns. Although the expected 5 May election would be during term time, students can vote by post and the Electoral Commission and National Union of Students are worried that students in halls of residence can find it hard to register to vote.
The seats where the Lib Dems say student votes can swing the election for them are: Bristol West, Cardiff Central, Leeds North West, Cambridge, Manchester Gorton, Sheffield Central, Oxford East, Newcastle-upon-Tyne Central, Liverpool Riverside, Holborn and St Pancras, Birmingham Yardley, Surrey South West, Taunton, Orpington, Haltemprice and Howden, Eastbourne, Isle of Wight, Dorset West, Bournemouth East, Wells, Canterbury, Cities of London and Westminster, Bournemouth West, Westmorland and Lonsdale.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize the given text about political parties in the UK elections focusing on students' votes. Let me read through it carefully.

The text is from Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader. He's claiming that students can influence seats by voting where they live if those areas have more students supporting them. The Lib Dems are aiming to gain new seats by having enough students support them. They say scrapping university fees and giving maintenance grants up to £2k would help their cause. The Tories also want to remove these fees, but the Labour Party is pushing for universities to charge higher fees with specific eligibility.

The text mentions that 14 seats are favorable to Lib Dems by making sure students vote in their home towns, while others are better suited for the Conservatives, who might cap students' ambitions.

Also, the text talks about students wanting solutions for environmental issues and the Iraq war. They're pushing for universities to be more accessible and open about student aspiration through vocational grants.

The electoral committee is concerned about students not being able to register on election day due to data protection, especially at a specific time. They plan to register by then but might need special methods.

I need to extract key points: Kennedy's campaign, target seats with sufficient student support, his plan for scrapping fees and grants, the impact on each party's targets, students' demands for solutions in environment and war, vocational grants, and electoral issues about registration.
</think>

Lib Dems aim to gain new seats by having enough students vote where they live. They propose scrapping university fees and offering maintenance grants up to £2k. The text also mentions that 14 seats are favorable to Lib Dems by ensuring students vote in their home towns, while others favor the Conservatives.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Lib Dems have targeted 14 seats in the upcoming general election where they believe students can decide the fate of MPs, by claiming that these votes could win them "27 new seats" at the poll. The party says that if all students vote in their university town, this would give them enough support to win an extra seat or two, taking them from second place to beat Labour and the Liberal Democrats respectively. The Lib Dems have named 14 seats where they believe students can decide the fate of MPs, along with the top-up fee plans proposed by Charles Kennedy, the party leader, to win student support at the London School of Economics. In addition, the party has highlighted the importance of tuition fees abolished by Labour and the Conservatives' policy of offering large student loans at commercial rates of interest. Shadow education secretary Tim Collins has set out a new scheme for vocational grant to help tackle skills shortages in vocational education. The seats are based on students registered near their university, but hall wardens are reluctant to register them, and some hall wardens can be hard to register due to data protection fears. If the election is held on 5 May, votes for the Lib Dems could swing the seat totals in favour of them, making it crucial for the party to win seats with a significant student support base.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Based on the analysis by the Lib Dem team, the election in the UK could be a pivotal moment for students' voting rights. In this scenario, students can decide who wins their votes based on changes to tuition fees and how they are managed. The Lib Dems, as the party that campaigns on reducing university costs, believe that scrapping university fees would help students make informed choices regarding their education. They also emphasize that these benefits should be shared among all students, irrespective of their background or area of study.

The Tories, on the other hand, argue that scrapping tuition fees would leave universities wholly dependent for their income on the "goodwill" of the chancellor. This implies that students may only vote for the party that promises to reduce these costs for them. The Labour party argues that higher education institutions should be responsible for managing student finances and allocate resources accordingly. They propose to let universities charge fees up to £3,000 a year with non-repayable support of up to £3,000 for students from low-income backgrounds. The Conservatives say they would introduce large student loans at commercial rates and also abolish university tuition fees altogether.

The Lib Dem analysis suggests that the seats where students can make a decisive difference in the election's outcome are: Bristol West, Cardiff Central, Leeds North West, Cambridge, Manchester Gorton, Sheffield Central, Oxford East, Newcastle-upon-Tyne Central, Liverpool Riverside, Holborn and St Pancras, Oldham East and Saddleworth, Manchester Withington, Islington South and Finsbury, Birmingham Yardley, Surrey South West, Taunton, Orpington, Haltemprice and Howden, Eastbourne, Isle of Wight, Dorset West, Bournemouth East, Wells, Canterbury, Cities of London and Westminster, Bournemouth West, Westmorland and Lonsdale.
phi:2.7b: The Liberal Democrats are targeting the student vote in 27 seats where they could win new members of parliament at the upcoming election by promising to scrap university fees and reintroduce maintenance grants for students. The party believes that this policy will gain them student support and help them win more votes than Labour, who would also end fees but cap people's ambitions, or the Conservatives, who would allow universities to charge fees of up to £3,000 a year. The Liberal Democrats have named the 14 seats where they could take over from Labour by winning enough students' votes, and the 13 where they could beat the Tories.
orca-mini:3b: The Liberal Democrats are targeting the student vote in 13 seats at the next election, hoping to win enough votes to win up to 27 new seats. Charles Kennedy, the party's leader, has claimed that students could decide the fate of MPs in some seats if they all vote in their university town. However, some students may also vote where their parents live. The Lib Dems are opposed to top-up fees and reintroducing maintenance grants, and want to abolish tuition fees altogether. Labour plans to scrap fees and offer non-repayable support of up to £3,000 to poorest students. The Tories would also cap people's aspirations with a cap on tuition fees and student loans at commercial rates of interest.
hermes3:3b: Lib Dem plan to win student votes in election, expecting 27 new seats if all students vote in university towns.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The Liberal Democrats aim to target the student vote in order to win 27 new seats at the next election, according to their leader Charles Kennedy. The party claims that scrapping university fees will secure support from students; however, the Tories also propose to end fees and Labour plans to cap people's ambitions. The Lib Dems have identified 14 seats where student votes can swing the election for them, leading them from second place in these areas. This includes winning over voters who may be registered to vote near their university town or those living in their parents' area. Students play a significant role in deciding the fate of MPs in certain constituencies, with their votes potentially determining the outcome of the election.

The Lib Dems aim to attract student support by pledging to scrap university fees and reintroduce maintenance grants. Kennedy emphasized that tuition fees deter students, particularly those from poorer backgrounds, and criticized student debt. He also highlighted student concerns about the environment and the Iraq war. Labour, which introduced tuition fees up to £3,000 with financial aid for poorer students, argues that both the Lib Dems and Conservatives would limit access to higher education. The Conservatives propose abolishing fees but replacing them with large student loans at commercial interest rates. The Lib Dems' electoral strategy assumes students vote in their university towns, though some may vote at home. Concerns exist about student voter registration, particularly in halls of residence. The election is expected on 5 May, with a registration deadline of 11 March.
